unnormalised: So, I've been seeing a lot of confusion around health identifiers lately, especially with the Ayushman Bharat Digital Mission (ABDM) rolling out. Thought I'd share what I know. It can get tricky with all the numbers!
normalised: So, I've been seeing a lot of confusion around health identifiers lately, especially with the Ayushman Bharat Digital Mission (A-B-D-M) rolling out. Thought I'd share what I know. It can get tricky with all the numbers!

unnormalised: Basically, a health identifier is a unique ID that links you to your health records. It’s like your Aadhaar, but specifically for healthcare stuff. This is supposed to make accessing your medical history easier for doctors, no matter where you go in India. Instead of remembering a bunch of different MR numbers, you just have your unique ID.
normalised: Basically, a health identifier is a unique I-D that links you to your health records. It’s like your Aadhaar, but specifically for healthcare stuff. This is supposed to make accessing your medical history easier for doctors, no matter where you go in India. Instead of remembering a bunch of different M-R numbers, you just have your unique I-D.

unnormalised: Now, there are a few key ones you should know about. The most prominent one right now is the Ayushman Bharat Health Account (ABHA) number, sometimes also called the Unique Health ID (UHID). Think of this as your primary health identifier under the ABDM. It’s a 14-digit number, something like 1234-5678-9012-34. Keep this safe, because its basically the key to unlock your records for any doctor or hospital authorized by ABDM.
normalised: Now, there are a few key ones you should know about. The most prominent one right now is the Ayushman Bharat Health Account (A-B-H-A) number, sometimes also called the Unique Health I-D (U-H-I-D). Think of this as your primary health identifier under the A-B-D-M. It’s a fourteen-digit number, something like one two three four hyphen five six seven eight hyphen nine zero one two hyphen three four. Keep this safe, because its basically the key to unlock your records for any doctor or hospital authorized by A-B-D-M.

unnormalised: Then you have your insurance policy numbers. Companies like HDFC Ergo, ICICI Lombard, and Star Health issue these. These are usually alphanumeric and can vary in length. Example: ICICI Lombard may give you "HLTH/MUM/2024/000123" and this connects your policy and claims to them. Each company also has its own internal medical record (MR) numbers too. You might have an MR number like 2024/APL/005 at Apollo Hospital in Hyderabad, and a different one, something like 12345678 at AIIMS Delhi. It is kind of annoying.
normalised: Then you have your insurance policy numbers. Companies like H-D-F-C Ergo, I-C-I-C-I Lombard, and Star Health issue these. These are usually alphanumeric and can vary in length. Example: I-C-I-C-I Lombard may give you "H-L-T-H slash M-U-M slash two thousand and twenty four slash zero zero zero one two three" and this connects your policy and claims to them. Each company also has its own internal medical record (M-R) numbers too. You might have an M-R number like two thousand and twenty four slash A-P-L slash zero zero five at Apollo Hospital in Hyderabad, and a different one, something like one two three four five six seven eight at A-I-I-M-S Delhi. It is kind of annoying.

unnormalised: Then there’s the Electronic Health Record (EHR) ID which is tied to specific hospitals or healthcare providers. Some hospitals already have pretty good systems in place. For example, hospitals might assign you something like "Patient-2023-10-0001" which will be tagged to all of your medical records within that particular institution.
normalised: Then there’s the Electronic Health Record (E-H-R) I-D which is tied to specific hospitals or healthcare providers. Some hospitals already have pretty good systems in place. For example, hospitals might assign you something like "Patient hyphen two thousand and twenty three hyphen ten hyphen zero zero zero one" which will be tagged to all of your medical records within that particular institution.

unnormalised: The government's aim is really good here. I think what ABDM is doing is basically trying to bring all this disjointed information under one unique ABHA ID.
normalised: The government's aim is really good here. I think what A-B-D-M is doing is basically trying to bring all this disjointed information under one unique A-B-H-A I-D.

unnormalised: Why is this important? It’s all about making healthcare more efficient and patient-centric. Imagine going to a new doctor in Bangalore. Instead of filling out tons of forms and trying to remember your entire medical history, you just give them your ABHA number (1234-5678-9012-34). They can then access your records securely, with your permission of course, giving them a much clearer picture of your health. It can help speed up diagnosis, reduce errors, and avoid unnecessary tests. Plus, it also has potential to improve the research in the long run. The only catch is everyone, including the smaller clinics and nursing homes needs to get onboard.
